title: The Impact of the 2011 Tōhoku tsunami on albatross in Hawaii
description: A regression analysis of the impact of the 2011 Tōhoku tsunami on albatross populations in Hawaii

This is an image of Holaniku, also know as Kure Atoll, the northernmost landmass in the Hawaiian archipelago. It is located at 28.3925° N, 178.2936° W and is within the Papahanaumokuakea National Marine Monument. Image Credit: Kure Atoll Conservancy
Introduction
The Hawaiian archipelago is home to thousands of albatross. The Northwestern Hawaiian islands, Papahanaumokuakea, are comprised of atolls, reefs, and pinnacles, where 95% of all Black-footed albatross and 99% of Laysan albatross nest (Arata, Sievert, and Naughton 2009). These low lying islands that serve as nesting habitat for these seabirds are at high risk of inundation from tsunamis (Reynolds et al. 2017). On March 11, 2011, a 9.0 earthquake hit the Tōhoku region of Japan. The earthquake lasted over 6 minutes, creating a tsunami that impacted coastal areas and island nations throughout the Pacific Ocean. Approximately 20,000 people lost their lives and thousands of marine and terrestrial species were killed or maimed.
Albatross live to be over 65 years old, have the largest wingspan of any bird, are monogamous rearers, and have nest-site fidelity (meaning they return to the same nest location every year). Three species of albatross breed in Hawaii, the Laysan (Phoebastria immutabilis), Black-footed (Phoebastria nigripes), and Short-tailed (Phoebastria albatrus) albatross. Laysan albatross are listed as near threatened due to threats from climate change to their habitat and breeding grounds and long-line fishing operations (Arata, Sievert, and Naughton 2009). The Short-tailed albatross almost went extinct in the early 1900s due to feather hunters and is currently listed as an endangered species in the United States(Wildlife Service - Alaska Region, n.d.). The UCN Red List of Threatened Species assessed the Black-footed albatross as near threatened in 2020(List 2017).
Researchers estimated the Tōhoku tsunami that between 26% - 52% of all Black-footed albatross nests and more than 275,000 albatross nests flooded from inundation waters throughout the Northwestern Hawaiian Islands (Reynolds et al. 2017). This post will attempt to analysis and quantify the impact of the Tōhoku tsunami on two Hawaiian albatross species, Laysan and Black-footed albatross. The Short-tailed albatross was not included in the analysis as there is only one breeding pair in Hawaii.

Show code

band_count <- albie_band %>% 
  group_by(species, year) %>% 
  summarise(total = sum(count))

  geom_point(aes(color = species,
                 shape = species)) +
  geom_line(aes(color = species)) +
  scale_color_manual(name = "Albatross species",
                     values = c("#9E7E8C", "#39ACB1"),
                     labels = c("Black-footed Albatross (BFAL)", "Laysan Albatross (LAAL)"),

# create new column for year pre-tsunami (0) and post(1), 2011 = post since the tsuanmi occurred before banding season began
band_count <- band_count %>% 
  mutate(t_event = case_when(
    year <= "2010" ~ "0",
    year >= "2011" ~ "1")) 

band_count$t_event <- as.factor(band_count$t_event)





Show code

# create two band count dataframes based on species
bfal_count <- split(band_count, band_count$species)[[1]]
laal_count <- split(band_count, band_count$species)[[2]]

title: Holaniku
description: An introduction to a remote atoll that I once called home
contents: Holaniku is known as the Kure Atoll state wildlife sanctuary, and is located 1400 miles (2300 km) northwest of Honolulu, Hawaii at 28° 25’N latitude and 178° 20’ W longitude. The sanctuary is managed by the State of Hawaii Division of Land and Natural Resources (DLNR) Division of Forestry and Wildlife (DOFAW) and is a part of the Papahanaumokuakea Marine National Monument (PMNM) created in 2006. In 1978, Holaniku was included in the Hawaii State Seabird Sanctuary system.
